questions.question: If a projectile's launch speed is doubled while keeping the angle constant, what happens to its horizontal range (on level ground)?
questions.explanation: Range $R \propto v^2$. If speed doubles, $v^2$ quadruples, so range quadruples.

questions.question: A ball is launched at 50 m/s at an angle of 53° above the horizontal. Given that $\sin53° \approx 0.8$ and $\cos53° \approx 0.6$, find the initial vertical velocity.
Which of the following does NOT affect the time of flight for a projectile launched horizontally from a height H?
options: All of these affect the time of flight.
questions.explanation: $t = \sqrt{\frac{2H}{g}}$ depends only on H and g, not on horizontal velocity.

questions.question: A toy rocket is launched with a vertical velocity of 50 m/s. What is its vertical velocity 2 seconds later? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$ and up as positive)
If air resistance is neglected, which component of a projectile's velocity remains constant throughout its flight?
questions.explanation: No horizontal force means horizontal acceleration = 0, so horizontal velocity is constant.

questions.question: A projectile is launched at 45° and reaches a maximum height of 20 m. What would happen to this height if the projectile's mass were doubled?
questions.explanation: Projectile motion (neglecting air resistance) is independent of mass.

questions.question: A ball rolls off a desk at 2 m/s and hits the floor 0.4 s later. What is the height of the desk? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
A projectile is launched at ground level. If the initial horizontal velocity is 12 m/s and the time of flight is 5 seconds, what is the total horizontal range?
At what point in its trajectory does a projectile have its minimum speed?
questions.explanation: Speed is minimum when vertical velocity = 0, which occurs at the highest point.

questions.question: A pencil is thrown vertically upward from the top of a 60 m tall tower. It reaches a maximum height of 20 m above the top of the tower before falling back down to the ground. Calculate the total time it takes for the pencil to hit the Earth from the moment it was thrown. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
